Award.AwardTitle: Academic Opportunities through Recruitment, Retention & Mentoring for Undergraduate Minorities in Biotechnology & Forensic Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Intellectual merit : This project's goals at Fort Valley State University (FVSU) are: 1) to achieve full retention of talented but financially disadvantaged undergraduates majoring in the sciences, while significantly reducing their time to graduation; 2) to recruit disadvantaged but talented scholars into STEM majors, making efforts to reach underrepresented minorities and; 3) to prepare them not only to pursue advanced degrees in STEM but also to play educational, leadership and managerial roles in STEM fields. The project targets 33 fulltime FVSU undergraduate students enrolling in Plant Science-Biotechnology (25 scholarships) and Biology/Forensic Science (8 scholarships). A Scholarship Screening and Selection Committee is formed to foster this program and consists of distinguished faculty members recognized for their mentoring ability and scholarship from diverse STEM fields as well as the Financial Aid Director. Each scholarship recipient is assigned a designated faculty mentor to guide the recipient's academic development. A rich array of opportunities are available to the scholarship recipients including a monthly seminar, tutoring, summer internship and service learning positions, field trips, faculty-student collaborative research, attendance at conferences, and alumni mentoring and comprehensive career counseling. The biotechnology and forensic science scholarships broaden the horizons of FVSU students in considering their career choices. Broader impacts: The geographic niche that FVSU serves includes south-central Georgia which is characterized by a high proportion of African American residents in rural setting that are often afflicted by persistent poverty. FVSU is a historically black university, and a vast majority (93% of enrolled students) are minority students that are characteristically under-represented in STEM fields. This project supports a larger STEM initiative that seeks to increase and strengthen partnerships, networks and collaborations between HBCUs and mainstream universities, state and regional forensic and health sciences laboratories, USDA and other agricultural enterprises. Through this project greater numbers of financially needy students are presented opportunities to successfully complete their baccalaureate degrees and go on to pursue graduate programs or enter careers in a broad range of science-related fields, meeting regional and national workforce needs. This program serves as a model for adapting the successful activities for other minority-serving institutions seeking to promote undergraduate mentoring programs in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes/  Intellectual Merit: (1) This S-STEM program immersed students in recruitment,  retention  and cutting- edge, multidisciplinary  research in emerging  areas of biotechnology  to broaden their participation. (2) All scholars were required  to participate in enrichment activities such as guest speaker presentations  from major campuses and to conduct independent  research at REU-Sites at major research institutions. (3) A total of 104 presentations  were made by STEM scholars at scientific meetings including at the Annual Research Day at the Capital and 27 students won awards  including 11 students who received  the 'Student  National Role Model Award'.  (4) All scholars judged at the Regional  Science Fair and assisted in K-12 science teacher workshops in biotechnology.  5) STEM scholars also attended GRE workshops, resulted in their placement in higher education and STEM workforce.   Program  participants tend to be first generation  college students (out of 67; 93% who received  the scholarship) and 96% are from under-represented group including 30 Scholars are male and 37 Scholars are female. From the current S-STEM funds, 19 Scholars (graduated  and 12 will be graduating by fall 2018 total of 31 S-STEM  Scholars (46%), including 8 are on leave  of absence due to unavoidable  circumstances (12%) and 3 STEM Scholars (4%) recipients leave  the program  and or switch to non-science  major and rest, 25 S-STEM scholars (37%) are planning to graduate in spring 2019-20.

Outcome s/Broa de r Impa ct: (1) after graduation,  these students will not only add to the diversity  of the technical workforce,  but also become effective  role models for younger URM students to motivate them to consider graduate  studies in STEM disciplines. (2) During the grant period, the program  was widely disseminated in Georgia and a total of 188 students applied for STEM scholarships. (3) Most Plant Science-Biotechnology  majors now graduate  within 4-5 years, retention of students within their majors has increased two-fold,  and participation in research internships has doubled (FVSU S-STEM program  was highlighted  in 2015, Diverse Issue in Higher Educ ation).  The retention and graduation  rates and the time to degree for STEM majors are among the highest in the University. Due to the strength of our program  and its ability to produce quality students, we are able to place our graduates  in key locations all over  the country at major institutions, federal labs and industry. Our graduates who received  NSF Scholarships are now working for the USDA/ARS, USDA/NRCS,  and USDA Forest Service, USDA Wildlife Services  as conservation  officers,  field technicians, land managers,  environmental  specialists, quality control managers,  biological science technicians, soil conservationists,  and are employed at the US Department  of Homeland  Security, Environmental  Protection Agency, USDA Biotechnology  Regulatory  Unit, CDC, Johnson & Johnson Company,  local high schools, environmental   consulting firms, and labs. Recent alumni went on to graduate  programs  at Cornell University,  University  of Florida, University  of Georgia,  Auburn University,  University  of Alabama at Birmingham,  Alabama A & M University,  Jackson State University,  Penn State University,  Tuskegee University  and Florida A & M university  and in professional  schools at Emory University,  Wake Forest University  and among many other institutions. (4) Disseminat ion  included  the FVSU website  listing  students  and  activities,  articles in the student newspaper   and  science blog  highlighti ng student  accomplis hm ents  to the community.
